DataElement.preferredName: Gynecologic Vulvar Tumor Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) 2009 Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Anatomic extent of the primary carcinoma of the vulva based on surgical pathologic examination.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to or practicing gynecology; pertaining to the health issues of women._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to or practicing gynecology; pertaining to the health issues of women.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to or practicing gynecology; pertaining to the health issues of women.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia.
The extent of a cancer in the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per request by D.Reeves. mc 6/5/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Vulvar Carcinoma Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) 2009 Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the vulva.  It usually affects elderly women but has been observed in premenopausal women as well.  The most frequently seen histologic type is squamous cell carcinoma. The most common site of involvement is the labia majora.  In many cases, the development of vulvar cancer is preceded by condyloma or squamous dysplasia._An international organization with a mission to promote the wellbeing of women and to raise the standards of practice in obstetrics and gynecology. They are the creator of staging criteria to describe the extent and spread of gynecologic malignancies._A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::2009_The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pM1 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pM1 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with distant metastasis (including pelvic lymph node metastasis). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pM1 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with distant metastasis (including pelvic lymph node metastasis). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pTX TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pTX TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer in which the primary tumor cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pTX TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer in which the primary tumor cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pT1a TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pT1a TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with tumor size 2 cm or less, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion 1.0 mm or less.  The depth of invasion is defined as the measurement of the tumor from the epithelial-stromal junction of the adjacent most superficial dermal papilla to the deepest point of invasion.  (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pT1a TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with tumor size 2 cm or less, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion 1.0 mm or less.  The depth of invasion is defined as the measurement of the tumor from the epithelial-stromal junction of the adjacent most superficial dermal papilla to the deepest point of invasion.  (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pT1b TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pT1b TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with tumor size greater than 2 cm, or any size with stromal invasion more than 1.0 mm, confined to the vulva or perineum. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pT1b TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with tumor size greater than 2 cm, or any size with stromal invasion more than 1.0 mm, confined to the vulva or perineum. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower/distal 1/3 urethra, lower/distal 1/3 vagina, anal involvement). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower/distal 1/3 urethra, lower/distal 1/3 vagina, anal involvement). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with tumor of any size with extension to any of the following: upper/proximal 2/3 urethra, upper/proximal 2/3 vagina, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to pelvic bone. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with tumor of any size with extension to any of the following: upper/proximal 2/3 urethra, upper/proximal 2/3 vagina, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to pelvic bone. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Vulvar Carcinoma Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics Integer::2009 Stage
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the vulva.  It usually affects elderly women but has been observed in premenopausal women as well.  The most frequently seen histologic type is squamous cell carcinoma. The most common site of involvement is the labia majora.  In many cases, the development of vulvar cancer is preceded by condyloma or squamous dysplasia.:An international organization with a mission to promote the wellbeing of women and to raise the standards of practice in obstetrics and gynecology.  They are the creator of staging criteria to describe the extent and spread of gynecologic malignancies.:A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::2009:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the vulva.  It usually affects elderly women but has been observed in premenopausal women as well.  The most frequently seen histologic type is squamous cell carcinoma. The most common site of involvement is the labia majora.  In many cases, the development of vulvar cancer is preceded by condyloma or squamous dysplasia.

An international organization with a mission to promote the wellbeing of women and to raise the standards of practice in obstetrics and gynecology. They are the creator of staging criteria to describe the extent and spread of gynecologic malignancies.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
